docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted today to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a politically charged showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses. The vote was 57 to 43. Four Democrats joined 53 Republicans in support of the bill, while 2 Republicans and 41 Democrats voted against it.

headline.main: SENATE APPROVES BIG CUT IN TAXES, COURTING A VETO

docs.abstract: Senate votes 57 to 43 to cut taxes by $792 billion over next 10 years, moving Republican-controlled Congress to showdown with Pres Clinton over how nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses; bill would cut personal income taxes by reducing lowest tax rate to 14 percent from 15 percent starting in 2001; would give a tax break to many married couples, expand Individual Retirement Account program, create a deduction for some health insurance costs and reduce inheritance tax on large estates; most of bill's provisions, which also include breaks for business and special-interest groups, would be phased in gradually as expected surpluses grow, and some would not be fully effective until 2009; of total of $792 billion in tax reductions over 10 years, only $4.1 billion would take effect next year; Sen William V Roth Jr, Delaware Republican, is main author of measure; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate voted today to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a politically charged showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Votes to Cut Taxes By $792 Billion in 10 Years The Senate voted to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses. The vote was 57 to 43. Four Democrats joined 53 Republicans in support of the bill, while 2 Republicans and 41 Democrats voted against it. The bill would cut personal income taxes by reducing the lowest tax rate starting in 2001. It would give a tax break to many married couples, expand the Individual Retirement Account program, create a deduction for some health insurance costs and reduce the inheritance tax on large estates. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: An unexpected spike in an important inflation warning signal that tracks labor costs spooked financial markets yesterday, overshadowing a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring. Despite the reassuring signs that the economy was not overheating, both the stock and bond markets fell sharply after the Labor Department reported that the employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from the first to the second quarter of the year, its biggest gain in eight years. The measure tracks changes in total compensation -- wages and salaries, of course, but also fringe benefits like health insurance and pension contributions. Both benefits and pay leapt, with the biggest increases coming in the highest- and lowest-paying industries.

headline.main: Jump in Labor Cost Prompts Fear of Rising Interest Rates

docs.abstract: Labor Dept reports that employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from first to second quarter of year, its biggest gain in eight years; stock and bond prices fall sharply in wake of report; investors appear concerned that Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan might raise interest rates in near future as preventive measure against rising prices; analysts say financial markets may have overreacted to threat of inflation; Commerce Dept reports that gross domestic product expanded at modest 2.3 percent annual pace; graph (M)
docs.snippet: An unexpected spike in an important inflation warning signal that tracks labor costs spooked financial markets yesterday, overshadowing a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring.    Despite the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though I am a Republican Congressman, I am also a doctor, and I have continued to treat patients and deliver babies in Muskogee, Okla. I have experienced first hand the frustrations that have pushed managed care reform to the forefront of the Congressional agenda. Indeed, after treating patients, I usually return to Washington with a new horror story about a health insurance bureaucrat who has arbitrarily denied care to one of my patients.
docs.abstract: Republican Rep Tom A Coburn Op-Ed article asserts that as a doctor he cannot support his party's managed care bill because it ignores needs of vast majority of Americans; contends that Senate bill has three major flaws; says it gives insurance companies rather than doctors authority to decide what care is medically necessary; says it falls short of establishing independent external appeals process for patients who have been denied coverage; says most people enrolled in HMO would still be unable to choose their doctor; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A press of eager diners followed the boomlet of favorable reviews about Tabla and Eleven Madison Park, the new dining establishments owned by the empire-building Manhattan restaurateur Danny Meyer. So what could be bad? Well, for starters, it was eight long weeks after the debut before he could open Eleven Madison Park for the lucrative lunch trade. Worse, it took eight full months for Tabla to be able to offer that perennial profit maker, Sunday-night dinner.

headline.main: Waiters, a Newly Rare Ingredient; Suddenly in Demand, They Have Become Demanding

docs.abstract: Article discusses growing demand for waiters and other restaurant workers in New York City; with new upscale restaurants opening at record levels, city is in throes of what is described as escalating skilled-labor crisis; employee shortage is changing nature of restaurants' employer-employee dynamic and transforming culture of dining trade; industry officials comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking $42 million from chiropractors, doctors and others in New Jersey it has accused of submitting false insurance claims for automobile accidents. In a lawsuit filed in State Superior Court in Bridgewater, N.J., that names 67 medical professionals and organizations, Allstate said it was seeking triple damages as compensation for the $14.1 million it spent on what it called false treatments.
docs.abstract: Allstate Corporation files suit in NJ Superior Court, Bridgewater, that is seeking $42 million from chiropractors, doctors and others in New Jersey that it has accused of submitting false insurance claims for automobile accidents (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the Giants and the Jets open their training camps, the heat is on. Not just this summer's scorching heat, but the quarterback heat that is always on. The Giants must decide on their quarterback, the Jets must decide on their quarterback's bodyguards. The Jets know Vinny Testaverde is their quarterback, but they also know that if they are to represent the American Football Conference in Super Bowl XXXIV, they must plug the leaks in the dike protecting him from the ever rising tide of opposing pass rushers.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Deciding On a Passer And a Line

docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses outlook for New York Jets and New York Giants as both teams open training camp; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Republican leadership, facing another rebellion from some moderate and conservative Republicans, backed away from plans to consider legislation on managed health care next week, with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert conceding that a vote before the August recess was now unlikely. In an effort to dispense with a politically potent issue that divides his party, Mr. Hastert, an Illinois Republican, earlier this week moved to bypass the normal committee process and put a senior group of Republicans in charge of writing a modified version of the Senate's managed care bill to bring to the floor for a vote next Wednesday.

headline.main: G.O.P. Rebels Force a Delay On Health Vote

docs.abstract: House Republican leadership, facing rebellion from some moderate and conservative Republicans, backs away from plans to consider legislation on managed health care, with Speaker J Dennis Hastert conceding that vote before Aug recess is unlikely; leaders favor limited approach to health care regulation; Reps Greg Ganske and Tom Coburn, who are doctors, and Rep Charles Norwood, who is dentist, are leading group of 20 to 60 Republicans who are far more sympathetic to approach favored by Democrats, who want to provide stronger protections covering all 161 million Americans with private health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut makes a critical point in the long-term-care debate when she notes that home is a better place for the elderly than any sort of institution (front page, July 26). Unfortunately, while the current system will pay upward of $40,000 a year for nursing-home care for those who have ''spent down'' their resources, it doesn't provide a community-based long-term-care benefit or any adequate support for concerned caregivers who want to provide their frail parents with a dignified life at home.

headline.main: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give

docs.abstract: Dr Bruce Leff letter, commenting on July 26 article on long-term care for elderly, says while current system will pay upward of $40,000 annually for nursing home care for those who have spent down resources, it does not provide community-based long-term care benefit or any adequate support for concerned caregivers who want to provide frail parents with dignified life at home (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a doctor who follows many patients in nursing homes, I find the complaints expressed by Ann R. Langdon (Op-Ed, July 27) to be mystifying. To suggest that the drugs used in nursing-home populations are prescribed for the convenience of the staff is a breathtakingly assertion.
